asset.about: A punt got James Boyce across the harbour to Sydney Infirmary in Macquarie Street. He died a few hours later.
asset.body:
Wood-cutter James Boyce was chopping down a tree in Chatswood when it fell on him causing multiple injuries. Head, ribs, lungs, leg. You name it, he copped it. Witnesses said a bone was protruding from his left foot.

It took an hour-and-a-half to get him to St Leonards in a cart and another three hours to Milsons Point.

A punt got him across the harbour to Sydney Infirmary in Macquarie Street. He died a few hours later.

Mr Boyce, of uncertain age, suffered terrible agony by a tedious rumbling journey in a springless woodcart rattling across the cobblestones of Sydney.

It was the fourth such case known to Frank B Treatt according to his letter to the Sydney Morning Herald published on January 7, 1886.

The phrase going to hell in a handcart comes to mind.

Such was the lobby for a hospital on the North Shore that fundraising through a local exhibition (a sort of GoFundMe of the day) led to the building of a cottage hospital in Willoughby two years later. Then there were 14 beds and a handful of nurses.

"It was simply untenable that the ill and injured had to make the arduous journey across the harbour."

These are the words of Deb Willcox, chief executive of Northern Sydney Local Health District and Alison Zecchin, general manager of Royal North Shore Hospital in the forward of a coffee-table book marking the 130-year history of the hospital published next week.

"What began as a little college hospital has grown into a renowned teaching hospital with a stellar reputation for medical expertise, patient care and cutting edge research," they write.

As you may envisage, there were a few milestones along the way.

Science, then as now, dictated contemporary nursing thinking. In the Carey Ward of 1914 nurses removed flowers from the ward at night because it was believed they deprived patients of oxygen.

At least surgeons could see what they were doing in 1916 when two powerful lights were installed once the marvel of electricity became available. No more excuses for whipping out the left when it was the right that was playing up.

Another picture captures the moment in 1930 when a young child looks on pensively as a nurse wields a hammer over a small anvil, apparently preparing a splint for a damaged limb.

Contrast the labour ward of 1921 to a modern delivery suite. Nurse attire was then still very Florence Nightingale. The steel frame beds were very unforgiving.

The beds hadn't improved much by the 1930s when diptheria and scarlet fever accounted for some 350 cases a year.

Hospital policy must be indoctrinated to all employees, as the staff manual of the late 1970s indicates. Wards may be classified as smoking or non-smoking wards. Individual wards may be divided into smoking and non-smoking areas.

Tailored slacks should not be worn by female staff during November through to April. And still on clothing, it adds: "Show respect by allowing patients to retain the maximum amount of clothing possible which still enables you to perform necessary tasks."

Fast-forward and the world of hospital care is in another era. The Surgical Education Research and Training Institute means surgeons can practise on a dummy. A modern hi-tech training dummy can cost as much as $370,000.

Apart from the obvious work of surgeons, psychologists and physiotherapists, there is an army of support and ancillary staff in the modern day Royal North Shore Hospital.

There's the roster of chaplains (as well as a Buddhist nun), technicians who make sure complex machines keep working, 550 volunteers, 2200 nurses, sheepdog Sam who makes bedside visits and visiting clown doctors to keep kids cheerful.

The words of Jim McLeish, 87, from Hornsby who undergoes dialysis three times a week, might apply to the multitude of skills and life-saving services offered by RNSH.

"No-one wants to be on dialysis but if you need it, this is a great place to have it."

data.caption: Royal North Shore Hospital's current labour ward.
Royal North Shore Hospital labour ward in 1921.

headlines.headline: Hell in a handcart no longer the way to hospital

authors.bio: Tim Barlass is a Senior Writer for The Sydney Morning Herald
authors.name: Tim Barlass
authors.title: Senior writer

asset.about: The government has struggled to entice contractors to bid for the construction of an underground interchange at Rozelle due to its complexity and risk.
asset.body:
The loser of the tender to build an underground motorway junction in Sydney's inner west as a part of WestConnex will receive up to $20 million in compensation from NSW taxpayers.

The government has struggled to entice large contractors to bid for the interchange – which will be dug to as deep as 65 metres – at Rozelle due to its complexity and construction risk.

The state's roads agency took control of the interchange last year from the corporation set up to oversee WestConnex after from a joint venture of construction giants Lendlease, CPB Contractors and John Holland.

In an attempt to get another party interested, the agency has since offered to compensate the unsuccessful bidder up to $20 million.

Roads and Maritime Services said it was standard practice for governments to reimburse bidders for “certain costs incurred during the bid phase”, such as expert advice and early design work.

“Design and construction firms incur significant expense when bidding for infrastructure projects,” it said in a statement.

“Reimbursement promotes competition in the tender process, ensuring the best value for taxpayers.”

More than five years ago, the state offered to compensate the losing bidders in the from Chatswood to Rouse Hill.

Shortly before the latest tender closed several weeks ago, Lendlease pulled out of the joint venture bid for the interchange, leaving John Holland and CPB vying against a consortium of Italian contractor Salini Impregilo, Korea's Samsung C&T and Australia's Clough.

Lendlease's engineering business has been under pressure from underperforming projects. In NSW, the it is building with French company Bouygues in Sydney's north is running six months' late, which will delay its opening to motorists until 2020.

The company said in a statement that it had pulled out of bidding for the Rozelle interchange after “careful consideration of our current projects and future pipeline”.

“Lendlease has to be disciplined with which projects it bids for,” it said.

The Rozelle interchange will be complex to build because it will comprise three levels of tunnels and scores of entrances and exits, including a link to the

The roads agency has repeatedly said that the interchange will open in late 2023 despite toll road company Transurban telling investors recently that it expects it to open by mid 2024. A Transurban-led consortium

It also emerged last month that the state will have to pay penalties of $2.3 million to the new owners of WestConnex if the Rozelle interchange is six months late opening.

A price tag of $7.2 billion was put on stage three of WestConnex, which comprises the Rozelle interchange and twin tunnels between St Peters and Haberfield.

While Transurban will contribute to the cost of the 7.5-kilometre twin tunnels, the full cost of the Rozelle interchange will be borne by the roads agency.

data.text: competition to run Sydney's north west metro rail line

data.caption: The interchange is regarded as the most complex part of WestConnex to design and build.
The interchange will be up to 65 metres below the surface at Rozelle.

data.text: paid $9.2 billion last month for control of WestConnex.

headlines.headline: $20m in compo to be paid to losing WestConnex bidder

asset.about: In this Transport NSW video, Lee Lin Chin announces the closure of the Epping to Chatswood train line as undergoes upgrades for the Sydney Metro Northwest.
Most commuters travelled via Chatswood to get to the Macquarie Park precinct on Tuesday morning, the first test of changes to public transport services.
asset.body:
Sydney commuters have been urged to travel via St Leonards station to get to the Macquarie Park precinct in the city's north in order to relieve pressure on the busy Chatswood station during the seven-month shutdown of a rail line.

Declaring the start of changes to temporary services a relative success, Transport Minister Andrew Constance said about 10,000 people had used “Station Link” replacement buses on Tuesday morning as they returned to work after the long weekend.

The bus services were frequent, but lines of passengers waiting to use them were long during both the morning and evening peak, prompting many to express frustration and concern about how the situation may worsen when school holidays conclude.

“This is never easy. It's just vital that people get used to new travel patterns and then at the same time making sure where possible, catch public transport, [and] don't rely on your motor vehicle,” Mr Constance said.

to allow it to be converted to carry single-deck metro trains, forcing as many as 20,000 commuters a day to change their travel patterns over the next seven months.

The 13-kilometre line will become part of the which will extend from Rouse Hill in the north-west to Chatswood.

Mr Constance said commuters had heeded messages to re-time their travel if they could, and plan their trips, but he warned that there was still “a long way to go”.

“Those travelling from the city, the south, the east who might be going to, for example, Macquarie University or Macquarie Park, please disembark your train at St Leonards and then of course the Station Link number four bus,” he said.

“We think we can ease some of the pressure at Chatswood if people get off at St Leonards. Chatswood was the hotspot this morning.”

About 114 buses operated on Tuesday morning from five locations in and out of the Macquarie Park precinct, home to Macquarie University and large companies such as Optus.

Transport for NSW coordinator-general Marg Prendergast said most commuters seemed to travel to Chatswood to get to Macquarie Park or the university on Tuesday morning.

“We really want to recommend that St Leonards is the way to go. It is a faster trip and we have a more frequent service,” she said.

She said queues formed quickly when trains stopped at Chatswood, resulting in commuters waiting for about 10 minutes “at worst”.

However, the high-frequency Station Link bus services were able to reduce the queues relatively quickly.

Ryde major Jerome Laxale said said the real test of the replacement services would be on October 15 when schools reopened after two-week holidays.

“A lot of the roads on approach to Macquarie Park have schools on them, and they will probably struggle the most. You will not only have the university traffic but school traffic,” said Mr Laxale, who is Labor's candidate for Ryde in the 2019 state election.

with Jenny Noyes

data.caption: Passengers board replacement Station Link buses at Epping.

data.text: The Epping-to-Chatswood rail line was closed on Sunday

data.caption: Commuters queue for replacement buses near Epping train station on Tuesday morning.

headlines.headline: 'This is never easy': 10,000 commuters put on buses amid rail line shutdown

asset.about: The ATO boss has turned his attention to Glencore, with the help of the Paradise Papers, and Ivan Glasenberg’s outfit is keen to shut that down.
asset.body:
Former north shore cop Chris Jordan has spent the last few years pursuing crimes on a somewhat larger scale than Chatswood Chase shoplifters — corporate tax evasion.

Now the Australian Taxation Office boss has turned his attention to Glencore, possibly with the assistance of some pilfered documents (depending on who you ask), better known as the Paradise Papers, and Ivan Glasenberg’s outfit is keen to shut that down.

We can reveal Glencore is taking Jordan to the High Court in a bid to prevent the use of thousands of files leaked from Bermuda law firm Appleby in the pursuit of unpaid taxes.

A writ was lodged with the court last Thursday.

The ATO is chasing the company over myriad things in legal action as complicated as the resources giant’s corporate structure.

Glencore hopes a win on the issue will set a precedent about what documents the tax office can use, with many of the 15 million documents leaked likely to be covered under legal professional privilege rules about communication between lawyers and clients.

The ATO is after Glencore in relation to operations at the Mount Isa Mines and the Murrin Murrin nickel mine, but we understand this particular writ is likely connected to the company’s “Project Everest” corporate restructure.

The Paradise Papers showed complex deals in April 2013 through its two Bermuda-based subsidiary, which reduced the company’s local tax bill significantly.

Has Jamie's hearing day finally arrived?

When former NSW Labor general secretary Jamie Clements was found guilty of unlawfully handing electoral roll information to a union boss in May 2017, head office said it would “quickly move” to expel him from the party.

But he’s still a member, which is no mean feat, considering the matter of his expulsion has been set down for a hearing by the party’s internal tribunal three times since then, including in November, May and finally last month.

Just get it over and done with, comrades. The next hearing date is set for October 15.

And there’s the persistent rumour mill that Clements, who resigned as the general secretary in January 2016 following allegations of sexual harassment being levelled at him, has desires to return, having taken to Twitter to critique the party (and others).

In one post, he even wrote he was “advising” Labor leader Luke Foley. A joke, we’re told.

Clements has also been spotted with frontbencher Chris Minns, who is often touted as a leadership hopeful, including at lunch with him near Kogarah and near his house last month.

But Clements, who is still a divisive figure within the party, has been friends with Minns for years and others have assured CBD that is about as far as the relationship goes.

As Clements knows from his new line of work advising Chinese billionaires, four is considered a particularly unlucky number. We’ll soon see if that’s for him or the party.

Committee carousel

We (almost) had a NSW Liberal musical chairs moment last week when Treasurer Dominic Perrottet attempted to wrest Multicultural Affairs Minister Ray Williams' seat from him.

Now we’ll have the Parliamentary Committee carousel.

With property dealmaker (and former Wagga Wagga MP) Daryl Maguire out of the picture, the chairmanship of the powerful Ethics Committee is up for grabs.

Enter North Shore MP Felicity Wilson, who was speculated to be interested in the job.

Her greatest hits include falsely claiming on a stat dec she had lived in the electorate when living nowhere near it, claiming she had two degrees when she had one, and alleging she had voted for John Howard in 2001 while living in Anthony Albanese’s electorate.

So wiser heads prevailed, and Wilson will not be elevated to chair a committee on ethics.

Instead, Premier Gladys Berejiklian has nudged Manly MP James Griffin to move spots, freeing up a position for Wilson as chair of the Legislation Review Committee.

Just in time for the pre-selection battle for her seat.

Porcelain gazing

Forget Laura Tingle at the ASEAN Business Summit.

Emma Alberici, the ABC’s chief economics correspondent, is scheduled to host a forum about the future of toilets sponsored by “water solutions business” Caroma.

Held in three weeks, the event will launch The Bathroom of the Future report.

It’s a welcome distraction from the debate over Alberici’s corporate tax analysis and news report.

As she points out (repeatedly), the review of the analysis found no factual errors (although it was “removed for review and republished with significant changes”).

But the reports were such an accomplishment it took news director Gaven Morris just six minutes to raise concerns about the piece.

data.caption: ATO Commissioner Chris Jordan is facing a High Court lawsuit filed by Glencore over the Paradise Papers.
Former NSW ALP general secretary Jamie Clements faces expulsion from the party at a hearing scheduled for October 15.
Liberal MP Felicity Wilson is likely to be elevated to the chair of a committee after the resignation of Wagga Wagga MP Daryl Maguire created a vacancy.
High-profile ABC journalist Emma Alberici will facilitate a discussion about the bathroom of the future as part of a University of Technology Sydney event.

headlines.headline: CBD: Glencore takes ATO boss to court

authors.bio: Kylar is The Sydney Morning Herald and The Age's CBD columnist. He recently covered federal politics, business and NSW politics for News Corp.
